speaker: Dan Patrick
vclaim: Leticia van de Pootie "Voted to give illegal immigrants in this country free health care -- not emergency health care but full free health care."
date: stated on September 29, 2014 in a debate in Austin:
title: Unlike Dan Patrick Van De Pootie's claim, he didn't vote for free health care for immigrants.
text: In the only discussion between the main party candidates for the post of Deputy Governor of Texas, Republican candidate Dan Patrick, along with his objections to the Texas law written by his democratic opponent, allowed some children living in the state without a legal permit to qualify for university education in the state. :: Patrick, Senator of Houston, went on to say on 29 September 2014, that after the adoption of the Law Education Proposal in 2001, the State of Sin. Leticia Van De Pote of San Antonio, a democratic candidate, supported another questionable step. "I voted to give illegal immigrants in this country free health care -- not emergency health care but full free health care," said Patrick. "That was almost seven years ago and this law did not pass." We were curious about the vote described. By e-mail, the spokesman for Patrick Alejandro Garcia said that Patrick had been referring to the vote of Van De Pote on a proposal approved by the Senate in 2003, Senate Bill 309. Garcia said that the legislation required local hospitals to provide emergency care for patients regardless of their immigration status. The opponents claimed that the bill would raise health-care costs and raise taxes to provide care for illegal immigrants. This measure is supported by Van De Bot, knowing that it would benefit illegal immigrants at a cost to taxpayers." Garcia wrote. We've been this way with Patrick before. In May 2014, we assessed his false claim that the Senate had previously approved free health care for illegal immigrants. Let's split up again. Members of the Senate, including Van De Bot on 5 May 2003, approved the proposal, which, on 5 May 2003, the Senate journal summarizes as "the provision of health care services regardless of the immigration status of the person." At that time, Patrick, a television host, was not yet a member of the Senate. The legislation provides that any city, province or public hospital may "use funds from local sources to provide health-care services to a person without regard to his or her immigration status, and establish a cost-sharing system for persons receiving health-care services." At a hearing held by the Committee in April 2003, writer Sin Mario Gallegos, Do-Hoston, said that hospitals were allowed to take advantage of local revenues to provide preventive services to residents regardless of the patient ' s immigration status. Sylvia Garcia, then Commissioner of Harris County, testified that the proposal would speed up outpatient services, emerge early from health problems and save money with fewer visits to emergency rooms. Proponents described the legislation as vital after the then United States Attorney General (and the next Senator in Texas) issued an advisory opinion in July 2001 stating that unless legislators allowed the Harris District Hospital (and others, presumably) to provide preventive services to patients regardless of their immigration status, the province could not provide such care without violating the Federal Act on Personal Responsibility and the reconciliation of employment opportunities of 1996, which required state legislatures to intervene if states wanted to move forward and do so. On February 1, 2021, Tom Cotton mentioned in an interview with Fox and friends "Many of these arriving immigrants, we have no way of checking their background for either health or security." In particular, the Corinne letter indicated that some health services had already been provided to patients regardless of their immigration status - as provided for in the Federal Act. According to Cornen ' s letter, the province is obliged by law to provide emergency care to residents regardless of their legal status. Lance Loensford, spokesman for the Texas Hospital Society, who describes itself as the political and educational defender of more than 430 hospitals and health systems throughout the state, told us a federal law from the 1980s, the Emergency Medical Treatment and Labour Act, making free emergency care available to illegal immigrants. According to a federal website, this law requires hospitals to participate in medical care that provides emergency services to provide a medical examination when applying for an emergency, including active work, regardless of an individual ' s ability to pay. The Corinne letter also stated that federal law allows public health services, including immunization, testing and treatment of symptoms of infectious diseases. However, he wrote that the 1996 Act provided that no other health benefit could be provided in the states or in the local areas unless the state law " positively provided for such capacity." Mike Stafford, Harris County Attorney General, replied to Cornen's letter that we advise the district hospital to stop giving reduced preventive care because it violates federal law, according to the story of Associated Press News on July 12, 2001. "It's up to the Texas legislature to intervene now, and if they want to create an exception for this, it's allowed," Stafford said. In 2003, Senate Bill 309 died in the House of Representatives, although advocates, including Lonesford, said that the authorization for such services had been completed in House Bill 2292, a major reform of health-care agencies in 2003. Article 285.201 of the Texas Health and Safety Act "prove positively" the eligibility of undocumented residents for non-emergency public health benefits locally funded by public hospital districts. In the end, did the legislation extend free health care for illegal immigrants? When asked about this, King Heller, Deputy Head of the Harris District Hospital Department, telephoned that the area was already providing non-emergency services when the matter reached legislators. Heller stressed the soft quality of the proposal; leaving funding and service delivery to local governments. Finally, Heller noted that the Senate version of the Act envisaged a system of cost-sharing among patients, which resulted. The Governor Patrick said that Van De Pootie voted to give illegal immigrants in this country free health care, not emergency health care, but completely free health care. The 2003 proposal on migrants did not provide comprehensive free health care. Instead, the measure allowed (and did not require) local governing bodies to provide (or appear to resume) non-emergency services to residents regardless of their immigration status, a measure that was expected to improve results and provide expensive emergency care that all residents were already entitled to under federal law. It is also important that the proposal envisages cost-sharing for patients. * Diagnosis: error. - The statement is not accurate.
